Hi Jan,

I agree, and as you touch on the idea of acceptance tests, you com=
e 
close to the one point I'd add.  Besides running time and number of 
fai=
lures, the other distinguishing feature of acceptance tests is that 
the in=
teracts often cross the system's boundary.  By that I mean input 
comes thr=
ough non-java interfaces such as GUIs, message systems, etc. 
and output in=
volve more side effects (i.e. go to places other than 
back to the source).=
  In some cases, these can be shoehorned into a 
Java interface (e.g. httpu=
nit) but this is often where the need for 
other tools comes in.

The reaso=
n for fine-grained testing is that large-grained tests are 
overwhelmed by =
combinatoric explosion of conditions long before they 
achieve reasonable c=
overage.  The "unit" is usually a single class.  
The system can be tens to=
 thousands of classes.  For small systems, 
the gap may be small enough tha=
t unit and acceptance tests are 
sufficient.  

Often, however, it is usefu=
l to have integration tests in between.  By 
testing clusters of collaborat=
ing classes, integration tests can 
further reduce the number of acceptance=
 tests needed to achieve 
reasonable coverage.  The thing integration tests=
 have in common with 
unit tests is that by being entirely within the syste=
m boundary, they 
can reuse much of the Java infrastructure, including JUni=
t, mock 
objects, etc.

Best regards,
Lance
